awd_titl_txt: Conference: Windows on the Universe: Establishing the Infrastructure for a Collaborative Multi-messenger Ecosystem
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed conference, to be held on October 16-18 in Tucson AZ, will bring together government agencies and expert scientists in the field of Multi-Messenger Astronomy (MMA) electromagnetic follow-up. Sessions will focus on identifying pathways that increase the coordination of follow-up MMA campaigns, reducing operational redundancy across the network of ground- and space-based observatories, and fostering collaboration in the MMA community. The community will be invited to review the current state of follow-up resources, report on existing collaborations and partnerships, and identify potential obstacles to success. The conference will develop concrete ideas that will be disseminated within a public white paper. The findings of the conference will help develop the scope of an FY2024 NSF solicitation dedicated to funding coordination infrastructure and efforts among the follow-up community. This proposal requests funding to host the workshop and to support participant attendance across multiple fields in the MMA community. All conference participants are required to read and agree to the ISEE code of conduct that outlines expectations for behavior and confidential and non-confidential reporting options for anyone who experiences misconduct.

With gravitational-wave and particle detectors now routinely observing events through new windows upon our dynamic Universe, we have entered the era of Multi-Messenger Astronomy. We have advanced resources to both identify the electromagnetic counterparts of Multi-Messenger events and then monitor and characterize their evolution. This activity requires coordination of the full range of available telescopes and their capabilities. While the scientific potential is staggering, future campaigns will be resource-intensive, expensive, and require considerable coordination, collaboration, and communication among the communities in order to deliver effective science. Motivated to foster effective Multi-Messenger follow-up, Organizers will invite the international observing community to participate in an open workshop. Organizers will ask the workshop participants to conceptualize community strategies and methods of tackling data sharing - i.e., telescope pointing plans, both planned and executed, observation outcomes, and calibrated data etc. Furthermore, we ask the workshop participants to identify pathways which will incentivize coordination, collaboration, partnership, and collegiality within the MMA community. This proposal requests funding to host a three-day workshop, limited in number to no more than 90 people. The requested funding would support the costs of a meeting venue (including hybrid capability, provide travel support for a subset of the participants, and meals for all attendees.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Conference: Windows on the Universe Outcomes Report

Award Number: AST-2336094

Project Overview:

With support from this award, NOIRLab in partnership with NSF and NASA hosted an in-person workshop on Multimessenger Astrophysics that was held in Tucson, AZ on 16-18 October 2023. The workshop title was “Windows on the Universe: Establishing the Infrastructure for a Collaborative Multi-messenger Ecosystem”. At this workshop, through talks, panel discussions, and breakout sessions we identified pathways to increase the coordination of follow-up MMA campaigns, how to reduce operational redundancy  across the network of ground- and space- based observatories, and ways to foster collaboration in the MMA community. Over the three days, with the 100 in-person attendees (roughly a third of which were able to attend cost-free from this grant)  and the 100+ more online attendees from the community, we reviewed the current state of follow-up resources, reported on existing collaborations and partnerships, and identified potential obstacles to success.

Intellectual Merit Outcomes:

The tangible outcome to this award was a White Paper outlining the results from the workshop and recommendations from the community for actions that should be taken by funding agencies to ensure a vibrant MMA ecosystem.  During the workshop we addressed the software and hardware infrastructure needs of the MMA community to improve coordination and reduce redundancy of ground-based EM follow-up of multimessenger events. The workshop allowed for lively discussions, and was a place for many to come together from all of the messengers (EM, neutrinos, gravitational waves, gamma rays) to identify the challenges associated with the unique science of MMA, including how to train and retain scientists with the specific skills needed for this new era in astronomy. Throughout the workshop and in the weeks following, we were able to produce the detailed white paper that proposed solutions on how to maximize the scientific return in this new window on astrophysical phenomena probed by multiple messengers.

 Broader Impact Outcomes:

In planning this workshop we were cognizant of the significant potential for broader impacts, reaching beyond the scientific community to engage and benefit various stakeholders. Because of this we made sure to include and extend invitations  to early-career researchers and those in marginalized groups. By bringing together both senior and early-career researchers from diverse backgrounds and specifically targeting underserved institutions, the workshop was a place to  foster interdisciplinary collaboration and knowledge exchange.  As part of  the invited talks we also made sure to include a specific session led by students at Vanderbuilt highlighting the success of their bridge program at attracting and retaining exceptional students from underrepresented groups. Through active discussion sessions engaging researchers with a wide range of expertise,  the workshop also helped provide participants with a deeper understanding of cutting-edge research methods and techniques in MMA astronomy, and how to promote diversity, equity, and inclusion.
